data.title: Albert Kwadwo Adu Boahen: A Biographical Sketch
data.meta_description: Albert Kwadwo Adu Boahen: A Biographical Sketch
data.text:
Felix had his primary school education at Etche in Rivers State; while he lived with late Chief M. O. Ogbuagu. On return from study leave, the late Rev. Canon H. O. D. Chiwuzie was posted to St. Augustine’s Grammar School, Nkwerre ; and as God would have it, late Felix was offered an admission for secondary education at St. Augustine’s Grammar School, Nkwerre, and the late Rev. H. D. O. Chiwuzie sponsored his secondary education. Felix’s academic records revealed excellent academic performance in secondary school from 1952 to 1956. One of the classmates and as well as bosom friend of Felix, the Venerable Herbert U. U. Okonkwo from Ojoto, who is very much alive and active, confirms and asserts that Felix was a man of academic distinction.

Oba mewa, Igbamewa literarily meaning "ten kings, ten different epochs" is a common proverb among the Yoruba people of southwestern Nigeria where Lagos State is geographically and ethnically subsumed. The proverb connotatively translates to the fact that the tenure of an incumbent ruler or office holder would be defined by its philosophy, approaches, style, achievements, pitfalls, and challenges. It is also used to reflect the historical, sociological, political, and socioeconomic dynamics that predominate the period a king or an office holder reigned. In the light of the import of this proverb, this paper presents the biographical sketch of the earthly sojourn of Oba Adeyinka Oyekan II, one of the twentieth century prominent monarchs of Lagos whose reign has been attributed as one of the longest in the history of Lagos spanning about forty decades. Specifically, the biography examines his emergence on the throne and the contributions of the reign towards the socioeconomic and political transformation of Lagos and its environs. The historical approaches to data collection (via extant literature and newspaper article especially) and interpretation are adopted.

This article examines the history ofakpeteshie(local gin) in Ghana from its illicit origins and widespread distillation in the 1930s to about 1967, when the Convention People's Party – seen as the ‘champion’ of theakpeteshieindustry – was overthrown.Akpeteshiedistillation proliferated when temperance interests succeeded in pressuring the colonial government into raising tariffs on imported liquor in 1930, just before the onset of a world-wide depression. Urban and rural workers, unable to afford expensive imported gin, became the patrons ofakpeteshie.
